This guide walks you through creating a blog using Next.js' [Static Generation](https://nextjs.org/docs/basic-features/pages) feature and [GraphCMS](https://graphcms.com/) through the [GraphCMS GraphQL API](https://graphcms.com/) and deploying the project with [Vercel](/).

<Image
  src="https://og-image.now.sh/**Deploy%20a%20Blog%20in%20Five%20Minutes**%20with%20Next.js%20and%20GraphCMS.png?theme=light&md=1&fontSize=100px&images=https%3A%2F%2Fassets.vercel.com%2Fimage%2Fupload%2Ffront%2Fassets%2Fdesign%2Fvercel-triangle-black.svg&images=data%3Aimage%2Fsvg%2Bxml%3Bbase64%2CPHN2ZyBmaWxsPSJjdXJyZW50Q29sb3IiIHhtbG5zPSJodHRwOi8vd3d3LnczLm9yZy8yMDAwL3N2ZyIgdmlld0JveD0iMCAwIDMzMCA3NSI%2BCiAgPHBhdGggZD0iTTM1LjI3IDEwbC04LjczIDUtOC43MyA1LTguNzMgNXYzMGw4LjczLTUgOC43My01VjM1bC04LjczIDVWMzBsOC43My01IDguNzMtNXYzMGwtOC43MyA1LTguNzMgNS04LjczIDUtOC43MyA1IDguNzMgNSA4LjczLTUgOC43My01IDguNzMtNUw0NCA1NVY1bC04LjczLTV6Ii8%%%2BCjwvc3ZnPgo%3D"
  width={2048 / 2.5}
  height={1170 / 2.5}
/>

For the frontend of this project, you will be using Next.js – the production-ready React framework. For the backend you will be using [GraphCMS](https://graphcms.com/) – a flexible headless CMS built 100% on GraphQL\*\*.

Two of the biggest selling points for GraphCMS are:

- **Full GraphQL Specification Support** this means you can query AND mutate content with GraphQL - enabling richer, more interactive experiences;
- **Highly Flexible, Drag and Drop Schema Builder** our powerful schema editor lets you visually build your API in an elegant and efficient manner, letting you build any product of any complexity to life, quickly.

<Image
  src={`${process.env.ASSETS}/guides/deploying-next-graphcms-in-5-minutes-with-vercel/gcms-nice-editor.mp4`}
  width={1280 / 1.5}
  height={720 / 1.5}
  oversize
  video
/>
<Caption>Preview of the schema editor.</Caption>

Follow this guide to have your own GraphCMS powered blog running in 5 minutes.

## Step 1: Create your content

First, [create an account on GraphCMS](https://graphcms.com).  
After creating an account, create a **new project from template** from the dashboard. Choose the Blog Project.

<Image
  src={`${
    process.env.ASSETS
  }/guides/deploying-next-graphcms-in-5-minutes-with-vercel/blog-starter.png`}
  width={1980 / 2.5}
  height={740 / 2.5}
/>

## Step 2: Create Your Next.js App and Create an Env file

To display your new blog and content, create a new [Next.js](https://nextjs.org/) application using [create-next-app](https://create-react-app.dev/), then run the following command and follow the wizard:

<Snippet
  dark
  text="npx create-next-app --example cms-graphcms cms-graphcms-blog"
/>
<Caption>Bootstrap a Next.js application from your command line.</Caption>

Navigate inside the directory.

<Snippet dark text="cd cms-graphcms-blog" />
<Caption>Navigating inside the directory and create a copy of envs.</Caption>

## Step 3: Connect to Vercel

[Create an account with Vercel](https://vercel.com/docs) if you don't have one, [install the CLI](https://vercel.com/download) and [link your project to a Vercel project](https://vercel.com/docs/cli#commands/overview/project-linking).

## Step 4: Add your API tokens from GraphCMS.

Locate the following variables names from your project, located in the .env.local.template file. You can find the values for these in the settings of your GraphCMS project.

<Image
  src={`${process.env.ASSETS}/guides/deploying-next-graphcms-in-5-minutes-with-vercel/get-tokens.mp4`}
  width={1280 / 1.5}
  height={720 / 1.5}
  oversize
  video
/>
<Caption>Finding environment variables in GraphCMS.</Caption>

After that, we can add our environment variables to Vercel using the CLI. Adding a variable follows the following pattern:

<Snippet dark text="vercel env add [ENVIRONMENT_VARIABLE_NAME] [ENVIRONMENT]" />
<Caption>Format of the Vercel command to add secrets.</Caption>

Vercel supports production, preview (like branch previews from Github) and development. Next we'll add each of our environment variables and the CLI will prompt us for the values.

<Snippet dark text="vercel env add GRAPHCMS_PROJECT_API production" />
<Caption>Format of the Vercel command to add your project API.</Caption>

Provide the API value.

<Snippet dark text="vercel env add GRAPHCMS_DEV_AUTH_TOKEN production" />
<Caption>Format of the Vercel command to add your project API.</Caption>

Provide the **dev** auth token value.

<Snippet dark text="vercel env add GRAPHCMS_PROD_AUTH_TOKEN production" />
<Caption>Format of the Vercel command to add your project API.</Caption>

Provide the **prod** auth token value.

<Snippet dark text="vercel env add GRAPHCMS_PREVIEW_SECRET production" />
<Caption>Format of the Vercel command to add your preview secret.</Caption>

Provide the preview secret token value. For more information on working with preview URLs, follow the example provided in the [GraphCMS NextJS guide](https://github.com/vercel/next.js/tree/canary/examples/cms-graphcms).

Now that are environment variables are in place, all you need to do is re-run the vercel deploy by typing:

<Snippet dark text="vercel --production" />
<Caption>Deploy your local project to production in vercel.</Caption>

And that's it! You've succesfully created a blog in GraphCMS and deploy it online. Now head back to GraphCMS and explore the app some more to discover even more functionality you can add to your website. [Our examples page](https://graphcms.com/examples) includes many more examples of things you can build with GraphCMS and our [documentation](https://graphcms.com/docs) should help you find your way.

To get a deeper understanding of what's happening under the hood, refer to this video by Luis Alvarez and Jesse Martin where they walk through the steps deploying GraphCMS to Vercel and discuss more of the technical functionality behind it.

<iframe
  width="560"
  height="315"
  src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/UCaKt6ljno0"
  frameborder="0"
  allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture"
  allowfullscreen
/>
